emailColumn.title: Albato: Building a SaaS Without Borders

authorInfo.title: About the Author
authorInfo.description: Mikhail Fedorinin, founder of Albato, shares his authentic journey of building a global SaaS company from the ground up. This interview series reveals the real challenges of international expansion, from failed attempts in Brazil to breakthrough success in the US market. Based on actual experiences from 2018-2024, these insights offer practical guidance for SaaS founders navigating global growth, cultural barriers, and the evolution from regional business to truly borderless operations.

keyTakeaways.title: Key Takeaways
keyTakeaways.description: SaaS international expansion requires three fundamental shifts: adopting English as your global business language from day one, mastering sales processes before scaling, and setting clear deadlines for market experiments. Success comes from rigorous planning with structured roadmaps rather than intuitive decisions. Cultural barriers are real - expect 3x longer timelines and higher costs than domestic expansion. Most importantly, focus on building a truly global product and team structure rather than just adding regional markets. The companies that thrive internationally think global from inception, not as an afterthought.

highlight.title: Global From Day One Strategy
highlight.description: Starting with your home market feels safer, but it creates complications later. If you want to build a global business, think globally from the beginning - use English for everything and set up international legal structures before you even have customers.

emails.subject: Remote Management Nightmares: Why We Needed Boots on the Ground
emails.body:
You asked about how we structured our ğŸ‘¨â€ğŸ’¼ğŸ‘©â€ğŸ’¼ team and managed responsibilities during our international expansion ğŸŒ. This was a significant challenge that evolved over â° time.

During our initial expansion to Brazil ğŸ‡§ğŸ‡· in 2019 ğŸ“…, we maintained a relatively fluid management approach rather than rigid â° time allocation âš™ï¸. As the company's creative leader rather than operational CEO (a role I only assumed 1-2 ğŸ“… years ago), I focused on identifying weaknesses, ğŸ“ˆ growth points, and guiding strategic direction while our COO handled operations ğŸ“‹.

This arrangement gave me flexibility to manage both CIS operations and Brazilian ğŸ‡§ğŸ‡· expansion simultaneously ğŸ”„. My approach was goals-based rather than â° time-based: **'I had a certain range of tasks that I would like to complete in a certain period of â° time.'** ğŸ¯ Without external investors requiring strict reporting ğŸ“Š, I had latitude in how I prioritized and scheduled my work ğŸ“….

For the Brazilian ğŸ‡§ğŸ‡· ğŸª market specifically, we hired a local Country Manager who was responsible for building the ğŸ‘¨â€ğŸ’¼ğŸ‘©â€ğŸ’¼ team and setting up processes âš™ï¸. On the CIS side, three people were actively involved in driving the international expansion: myself, Lesha Belyi (who has since left the company), and our CPO ğŸ‘¨â€ğŸ’¼. I served as the primary driver of the process, while our Country Manager in Brazil ğŸ‡§ğŸ‡· handled local hiring and process implementation ğŸ”§.

**Our management approach lacked rigid deadlines** - a shortcoming I now recognize âŒ: **'Unfortunately, we didn't have that, we actually blew a lot of ğŸ’° money and â° time on that ğŸª market because of that.'** Without clear timelines for evaluating success âœ…, we continued investing in Brazil ğŸ‡§ğŸ‡· longer than was optimal. Today, we always set clear deadlines for international initiatives to ensure we can pivot if necessary: **'You have to set some kind of limit - it didn't work out, and you switch the focus. Because you can try it like that to infinity.'** â™¾ï¸

In 2021 ğŸ“…, after struggling with remote management, our approach evolved ğŸ“ˆ. **Lesha traveled to Brazil ğŸ‡§ğŸ‡· for 3-4 ğŸ“… months with a clear mandate: either achieve significant progress or close the operation** âœˆï¸. This in-person presence made a substantial difference: **'We just then managed to make a breakthrough by doing it.'** ğŸš€ The face-to-face interaction addressed communication challenges exacerbated by language barriers (Brazilians ğŸ‡§ğŸ‡· generally don't speak English ğŸ—£ï¸ well, and we didn't speak Portuguese ğŸ—£ï¸).

highlight.title: Remote Has Limits
highlight.description: You can't manage international expansion purely remotely, especially in the beginning. Cultural and language barriers require face-to-face time. Set clear deadlines for your experiments - without them, you'll waste years and tons of money.

emails.subject: Three Country Managers, Three Failures: The Hard Truth About Hiring
emails.body:

**Over three ğŸ“… years, we went through three different Country Managers in Brazil ğŸ‡§ğŸ‡·**, each serving for approximately one ğŸ“… year. This pattern reflects our annual planning framework - we build models at ğŸ“… year-end for the following ğŸ“… year, making the end of each ğŸ“… year a natural point to evaluate performance and make decisions about continuing or changing direction ğŸ”„.

Our first Country Manager was a Brazilian ğŸ‡§ğŸ‡· who came recommended through our CPO Kolya's network ğŸ¤. Due to COVID ğŸ¦ , this person's work in [UEFA](https://www.uefa.com) had been disrupted, creating an opportunity for us to bring them into our company ğŸ’¼. Despite initial optimism âœ¨, we encountered cultural challenges that we hadn't anticipated: **'Brazilians ğŸ‡§ğŸ‡· are very much like that... At first it seemed that not a person, then a currant, now everyone knows some words, now let's do it right.'** ğŸ¤·â€â™‚ï¸

After a ğŸ“… year, we made our first change when we saw insufficient progress ğŸ“‰. **The key factor in this decision wasn't just missing targets but the absence of a clear plan for improvement**: **'The main criterion was that the ğŸ“… year has passed, and the dynamics, how far from what we discussed, and there is no any specific plan about what we are going to do about it - well, like such a red flag.'** ğŸš©

For our second Country Manager, we hired a woman who had lived in Brazil ğŸ‡§ğŸ‡· for many ğŸ“… years ğŸ . Our thinking shifted to: **'Maybe we'll find a person with intellect which is similar to ours', so that it would be easier to manage it all.'** ğŸ§  This approach showed better results - she successfully hired capable support staff who effectively converted incoming leads from our organic traffic ğŸ“ˆ. However, after another ğŸ“… year, we still weren't seeing the desired progress, as her product-oriented mindset didn't align well with our sales-focused needs ğŸ’¼.

Our third attempt involved recruiting a Brazilian ğŸ‡§ğŸ‡· from our competitor - someone who had lived in Australia ğŸ‡¦ğŸ‡º, worked at [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com), and had relevant sales experience ğŸ’¼. Once again, despite promising talks ğŸ’¬, actual revenue ğŸ“ˆ growth didn't materialize ğŸ’°.

**After these three attempts spanning approximately three ğŸ“… years, we ultimately decided to shift our focus to the American ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸ ğŸª market**, where we were gaining traction ğŸ“ˆ. This experience has been invaluable in shaping our approach to international leadership ğŸ‘¨â€ğŸ’¼. **We learned to distinguish between managers who can articulate a vision versus those who can execute effectively** ğŸ’¡. highlight.title: Execution Over Talk
highlight.description: Don't give endless second chances to country managers who can't deliver results. Look for people who can execute, not just talk a good game. If there's no clear improvement plan after a year, it's time to move on.

emails.subject: Marketing Missteps: Why Copy-Paste Strategies Don't Work Internationally
emails.body:
You asked about our marketing approach in Brazil ğŸ‡§ğŸ‡· and how it compared to our strategies in CIS and other ğŸª markets ğŸ“Š. This is an area where we've learned significant lessons ğŸ“.

For our Brazilian ğŸ‡§ğŸ‡· expansion, **we essentially replicated our local marketing playbook with minimal adaptation** ğŸ“‹. We analyzed what channels were most effective for [Zapier](https://zapier.com) (our competitor) in Brazil ğŸ‡§ğŸ‡·, found they matched what worked at ğŸ  home, and assumed this would be relevant for the entire ğŸª market. In retrospect, this assumption may have been flawed ğŸ¤”.

We focused primarily on marketers as our target audience ğŸ¯, emphasizing features like chat functionality ğŸ’¬, ad dashboards ğŸ“Š, and heatmaps ğŸ”¥. However, **we later discovered that our Brazilian ğŸ‡§ğŸ‡· competitor 'Luga' was targeting the payments sector instead** ğŸ’³ - which suggested we might have been focusing on the wrong ğŸª market segment entirely âŒ.

While the marketing channels themselves (social media ğŸ“±, search advertising ğŸ”) performed similarly to CIS in terms of mechanics âš™ï¸, our messaging and audience targeting likely needed greater adaptation ğŸ”„. We attempted to work with local influencers ğŸ“¸, proposing referral-based payment structures ğŸ’°, but struggled to gain traction. This points to another challenge: **'It's hard to just interact with the ğŸª market because you don't know the language ğŸ—£ï¸, it's not even hard for me how well we did it.'** ğŸ¤·â€â™‚ï¸

**Our approach has evolved dramatically as we've shifted focus to the American ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸ ğŸª market** ğŸš€. Rather than broad marketing campaigns ğŸ“¢, we now focus almost exclusively on outbound sales through highly targeted outreach ğŸ¯. We've developed a sophisticated process:

1. **We employ a dedicated data scientist whose role is to mine data and package it appropriately for outreach** ğŸ“Š. This includes identifying companies that fit our portfolio ğŸ“, finding the right decision-makers ğŸ‘¨â€ğŸ’¼, and generating specific 'signals' that make our outreach more personalized ğŸ¯.

2. **We analyze ğŸŒ websites, reviews on platforms like [G2](https://www.g2.com), and other data points to create highly targeted messages** ğŸ“. For example, if we notice a site has integrated three services, we'll approach them with a proposition to expand from three to hundreds or thousands ğŸ“ˆ.

3. **This personalized approach generates exceptional results because recipients perceive it not as a cold call but as if 'we came in, did some kind of audit' specifically for them** ğŸ”.

4. **We apply a multi-touch strategy, connecting with prospects on [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com), exposing them to content, and approaching the same company through different channels** (e.g., contacting both founders and CPOs with different messaging) ğŸ“±.

This system took approximately 18 ğŸ“… months to develop, but has proven highly effective âœ…. It creates interesting dynamics where prospects sometimes feel they're hearing about us from multiple sources simultaneously, enhancing our credibility ğŸ’.

For 2024 ğŸ“…, we planned to expand beyond pure outreach to include marketing activities that will help nurture prospects who don't convert immediately - including retargeting ğŸ¯, ğŸ“§ email marketing, and other standard approaches to complement our outbound sales efforts ğŸ“ˆ.

highlight.title: Local Markets Need Local Strategies
highlight.description: Don't just copy your home market playbook to new countries. Research local competitors' strategies and customer preferences. What works in one market might completely miss the mark in another - even if the channels look similar.

emails.subject: Our Biggest Mistakes: The Million-Dollar Lessons from Brazil
emails.body:
You asked about our biggest mistakes and most important lessons from our international expansion journey ğŸŒ. Let me share the critical insights we've gained - both from our missteps and our eventual successes ğŸ“.

**Our Primary Mistakes:** âŒ

1. **Insufficient ğŸª Market Analysis:** We entered Brazil ğŸ‡§ğŸ‡· without adequate research ğŸ“Š, relying largely on personal connections and intuition ğŸ¤”. A more rigorous analysis might have led us to choose a different ğŸª market or approach.

2. **Lack of Clear Planning:** We operated without a structured roadmap ğŸ—ºï¸, following our imagination rather than a disciplined strategy ğŸ“‹. As I reflect, **'Now with the States ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸, we are following the plan, we have a rigid model, and we are making sure that it is fulfilled. In Brazil ğŸ‡§ğŸ‡·, when we started, we did nothing of the sort, and now I can see, of course, that it was a completely non-serious approach.'** ğŸ“ˆ

3. **Missing Deadlines:** Without clear â° time boundaries for our experiments ğŸ§ª, we continued investing far longer than was optimal. Every experiment should have a deadline for evaluation and reconsideration ğŸ“….

4. **Excessive Second Chances:** We were reluctant to make personnel changes when needed ğŸ‘¨â€ğŸ’¼. **'It seems like we gave too many second chances. Even third chances, I'd say. It's okay to give second chances, not to give third chances.'** ğŸ”„

5. **Inefficient Resource Allocation:** Our casual attitude toward financials led to significant waste ğŸ’°. **'We basically poured a lot of ğŸ’° money, and as a result it seems that we could have been much more efficient.'** ğŸ“‰

**Two Critical Learnings:** ğŸ’¡

Despite these mistakes, we made two decisions that proved transformative for our business:

1. **Early Transition to English ğŸ—£ï¸ Communications:** **'We moved communications at one â° time pretty early on into English ğŸ—£ï¸. That's something that a lot of people don't do.'** This seemingly simple decision has had profound implications ğŸŒ, allowing us to operate as a truly international company. We can now hire talent globally without language barriers since all documentation and communication history exists in English ğŸ—£ï¸. What initially seemed like a minor operational choice has become a strategic advantage ğŸš€.

2. **Mastering the Sales Process:** **'The main achievement is that we went to Outreach, we took care of the story normally and we learned how to sell.'** ğŸ’¼ This has been the fundamental breakthrough in our international success âœ…. No matter how excellent your product ğŸ†, without an effective sales model, success is unlikely ğŸ“‰. Conversely, even mediocre products with exceptional sales processes often thrive: **'There are tons of examples where the product is complete shit, but it's fucking shit with sales and everything works.'** ğŸ“ˆ

This second point has been particularly eye-opening ğŸ‘ï¸. We've received recognition on [G2](https://www.g2.com), [Capterra](https://www.capterra.com), [Gartner](https://www.gartner.com), [Product Hunt](https://www.producthunt.com), and various shortlists - placing us among the top three CAC products globally ğŸ†. Yet these achievements, while helpful for credibility ğŸ’, have minimal direct impact on sales ğŸ’°. They provide 'social proof' that might slightly improve conversion rates, but they don't drive significant business on their own ğŸ“Š.

The reality of B2B SaaS sales remains unchanged: **'With selling, it's just hard, routine shit. You sit there and you make calls ğŸ“ and you write there and you run around in conferences there, that's kind of how it works. And, unfortunately, nobody has thought of anything else yet.'** ğŸ”„

Having our founder actively involved in sales has been critical - my partner who runs sales is personally present at every important ğŸ¤ meeting with major clients ğŸ‘¥. This hands-on leadership in the sales process has been a key factor in our eventual success ğŸ¯.

highlight.title: Sales Beats Everything
highlight.description: Awards and recognition are nice, but they don't pay the bills. Master your sales process and communicate in English from day one. These two decisions will matter more than any fancy product features or market analysis.

emails.subject: The Future is Borderless: How We Built a Truly Global SaaS
emails.body:
You asked about our current strategy after these experiences and how we're applying the lessons we've learned ğŸ“. Let me share where we stand today and our path forward ğŸš€.

After our extended experience in Brazil ğŸ‡§ğŸ‡·, **we've shifted our primary focus to the American ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸ ğŸª market**, where we're seeing stronger traction ğŸ“ˆ. We haven't completely abandoned Brazil ğŸ‡§ğŸ‡· - we maintain support there and continue to receive some clients ğŸ‘¥ - but we've stopped actively developing that ğŸª market ğŸ“Š.

Our strategic direction has also evolved ğŸ“ˆ. Initially, we struggled to choose between two products: an end-user tool (similar to [Zapier](https://zapier.com)) and a B2B solution ğŸ’¼. After analyzing our strengths and ğŸª market opportunities, **we've decided to concentrate on the B2B segment**: **'We realized that we can sell B2B, and it's clear how to build it, that is, we learned how to hire people there, and we learned how to organize this funnel.'** ğŸ¯

**We're now applying this B2B model successfully in multiple ğŸª markets, including Poland ğŸ‡µğŸ‡±**, with an emphasis on the American ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸ ğŸª market. While we still maintain our end-user product, which generates regular leads ğŸ“ˆ, we're not actively promoting it since we recognize the challenge of competing with established players like [Zapier](https://zapier.com): **'It is difficult for us to be cooler than [Zapier](https://zapier.com) there and what serious arguments can we come up with why we are better than [Zapier](https://zapier.com) except that we are much cheaper ğŸ’°, but for American ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸ customers it is not an argument.'** ğŸ¤·â€â™‚ï¸

**Our current operational approach centers around a remote-first model** ğŸŒ. We're based in Portugal ğŸ‡µğŸ‡¹ but sell primarily to the ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸ United States. This structure works well because we now have a clear understanding of our target audience ğŸ¯, know how to communicate with them effectively ğŸ’¬, and have developed appropriate marketing materials ğŸ“.

This model has proven remarkably effective: **'We now sell more in the States ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸ than many companies that have moved to the States ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸ and are trying to do things here.'** ğŸ“ˆ We've considered opening a US ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸ office ğŸ¢, but currently don't see sufficient benefit to justify the expense ğŸ’°.

Next, we plan to expand our marketing efforts beyond our current sales-focused approach ğŸ“¢. While outbound sales have driven our ğŸ“ˆ growth to date, we recognize the need to develop complementary marketing channels to nurture prospects who don't convert immediately ğŸ”„. We're currently seeking a head of marketing to build out these capabilities ğŸ‘¨â€ğŸ’¼.

**Looking ahead, our model is increasingly global rather than regional** ğŸŒ. We hire talent without regard to location ğŸ“ - our ğŸ‘¨â€ğŸ’¼ğŸ‘©â€ğŸ’¼ team includes people from Poland ğŸ‡µğŸ‡±, Italy ğŸ‡®ğŸ‡¹, Argentina ğŸ‡¦ğŸ‡·, and Chile ğŸ‡¨ğŸ‡±, all working remotely as part of a unified global operation ğŸŒ. **AI ğŸ¤– is further enabling this borderless approach**, allowing us to provide localized experiences (like support in native languages ğŸ—£ï¸) while maintaining a centralized operation âš™ï¸.

This evolution from regional business to **truly global operations** represents the culmination of our journey and the application of all the lessons we've learned along the way ğŸ“. We're no longer a company with international offices - we're a global company that happens to be headquartered in Portugal ğŸ‡µğŸ‡¹ but operates everywhere ğŸŒ.

**The future of SaaS is borderless** - and we're building that future today ğŸš€.

highlight.title: Think Global, Act Borderless
highlight.description: The future isn't about having offices in different countries - it's about building a truly global team and operation. Hire the best talent anywhere, use AI for localization, and focus on mastering your sales process rather than chasing regional markets.
